ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Understand climate systems and large scale processes that influence and drive different components of the climate system.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Great combination of theory of climate dynamics & its substance. Not too abstract, but not too down-to-earth!
Weaknesses: For the problem sets, it was sometimes very difficult to understand what the instructor was asking for. Perhaps this is due to my lack of exposure to common knowledge/assumptions in the field, but I would have found the psets more didactic with some more context.

I think a strength was the lectures on past climates and on ENSO, AMOC, and NAO. But a very prominent weakness for me was the large amount of redundancy in information from other courses like GFD, PWC, and PO. It would have been really nice if those were pre requisites such that we could have dived into newer topics in more depth as opposed to reviewing material from other classes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially for students interested in climate change & the theory underlying it!
I would because of the new material in it but I think I would also warn them that it is redundant if they took GFD and PWC so some classes might be kind of frustrating in that regard.
